article.name: USB Drive Test Overview
article.title: USB Drive Test Overview
article.body:
A USB drive test allows you to test your users on how they will react to finding an unknown removable storage device, such as a thumb drive.

If you navigate to Physical Tests > USB in your KSAT console, you can download test files and copy them to universal serial bus (USB) drives. Once the USB drives are set up, you can place the USB drives in planned locations. Then, you can use your KSAT console to see if your users are opening the test files. You can also see information such as where your users are opening the test files.

Alternatively, you can watch our USB Drive Test video.

USB Drive Tests Page

From the USB Drive Tests page of your KSAT console, you can view and manage all existing USB drive tests.

  1. + Create New USB Drive Test: You can click this button to go to the Create New USB Drive Test page and add details for a new test.
  2. Download CSV Report: You can click this button to download a report that shows details for all of your USB drive tests. This report will display each time a test file was opened, when macros were enabled, the IP address location for each failure, and more.
  3. Campaign Name: This column displays each USB drive test. To view more details about a test, click the test's name.
  4. USB Location, Total File Opens, Total Macros Enabled, Started on, and Completed on: These columns display the number of times a file was opened, the number of times macros were enabled, when the test was started, and when the test was completed.
  5. Status: This column displays the status of each USB drive test. For more information about the test statuses, see the list below:
    • Created: This status displays when the test has been created but has not started yet.
    • Started: This status displays when the test has started and is in progress.
    • Completed: This status displays when the test has ended.
  6. Actions: This column displays a drop-down menu with more actions to manage your USB drive test. For more information about the test statuses, see the list below:
    • Edit: Click this button to change information about your test, such as the name or location.
    • Delete: Click this button to delete your test.

Creating a USB Drive Test

To create a USB drive test, you'll need one or more USB drives and the ability to reach the KnowBe4 USB server domain.

Keep in mind that you may not be able to physically reclaim the USB drive again once your test begins.

The KnowBe4 USB server domain is the instance where your console is hosted, followed by the subdirectory /usb_campaigns/report/. For example, the United States USB server is https://training.knowbe4.com/usb_campaigns/report/. See our KnowBe4's Training Instances article for more information.

Important:If you do not configure the necessary connection to the above page, then data sent from the test files may be blocked and will not report any results to your KSAT console.

When you're ready to start a USB drive test, navigate to Physical Tests > USB in your KSAT console. Then, click + Create New USB Drive Test to create a new test.

Give your test a name, specify the location where you will leave the device, and add any notes that could be helpful for you to track. Click Create USB Drive Test once all details are entered.

  1. Name: Enter a name for your USB Drive Test.
  2. Location: Enter the location where you will leave the USB drive.
  3. Notes: Enter any details about this test, such as whether the test will be started before or after users have received training on USB drive safety.
  4. Create USB Drive Test: Once you have added all the information you want, click Create USB Drive Test.

Starting a USB Drive Test

Once you have created a USB drive test, you’ll be redirected to the test Overview page. You can also access this page by navigating to Physical Tests > USB in your KSAT console and selecting the test’s name. This page lists four steps to start your USB drive test. 

See the sections below for more information about these steps.

  1. From the Download Test File column, click the name of a test file to download it. You can download and use multiple test files in a single USB drive test.
  2. Copy the files to a USB drive. You can copy test files to multiple USB drives in a single USB drive test.
    Important:We encourage you to rename these files before saving them to your USB drive. We recommend using filenames that entice your users to open them, such as “Salaries2022.xlsx” or “BoardMeetingNotes.docx”.
  3. At the bottom of the page, click Start Test.
  4. Place the USB drives in your desired location.
Note:Users must have the appropriate programs installed on their computers to open and run the embedded scripts in the test files. Without a program to open the files, the test data cannot be sent back to your console.

Monitoring a USB Drive Test

To check the details of a USB drive test, navigate to Physical Tests > USB in your KSAT console. Then, click the name of the test you'd like to monitor. The Overview page displays the number of times a file has been opened, the number of times macros have been enabled, and a map of IP address locations where the failures occurred.

On the Details subtab, you can view a table that displays each time a test file was opened, when macros were enabled, and the IP address location for each failure. If macros were enabled by a user, the table will also display the user's username, display name, and computer name.

Ending a USB Drive Test

There is no specified duration for how long a USB drive test will run. When you're ready to stop monitoring the failures from a test, click End Test on the test overview page.Once you have ended a test, the test will not be updated with new data on opened files or enabled macros. If you would like to continue a test, click Restart Test on the test overview page.

Additional Resources

Check out the following articles for more information about USB drive tests:

My USB Drive Test Report Is Not Showing Macros Enabled

How to See the Internal IP Addresses of Users Who Have Failed a USB Drive Test

images.alt:
This image displays the **USB Drive Tests** management interface, with the **Overview** tab selected. The primary function is to list and manage ongoing or completed USB-based penetration testing campaigns.

**I. Top-Level Controls:**
*   **(a) Primary CTA:** A blue button labeled **+ Create New USB Drive Test** is positioned in the upper right for initiating a new campaign.
*   **(b) Reporting Function:** A link below the primary CTA provides the option to **Download CSV Report**.

**II. Campaign Data Table:**
The interface presents test results in a sortable data table, defined by the following headers:
*   **(c) Campaign Name:** Hyperlinked text identifying the test (e.g., "New," "PRTest").
*   **(d) USB Location:** Text field identifying the target location (e.g., "Test," "KST-1876").
*   **Total File Opens:** Numerical metric.
*   **Total Macros Enabled:** Numerical metric.
*   **Started on:** Date field (MM/DD/YYYY).
*   **Completed on:** Date field (MM/DD/YYYY).
*   **(e) Status:** Indicator displayed as a colored pill tag (e.g., "Started" (grey), "Completed" (green), "Created" (blue)).
*   **(f) Actions:** A dropdown menu control for row-specific modifications.

**III. Row-Level Actions:**
The **(f) Actions** dropdown, shown open for the second row, contains two functions:
*   **Edit** (with a pencil icon).
*   **Delete** (with a trashcan icon).
images.context: age of your KSAT console, you can view and manage all existing USB drive tests.

images.alt:
This screen displays the interface for creating a new USB Drive Test.

**Context and Navigation:**
*   **Title:** "Create New USB Drive Test" (H1 heading).
*   **Navigation Link:** "← Back to USB Drive Tests" located in the top right corner.

**Input Fields (Required and Optional Metadata):**
The form requires metadata input across three fields, sequentially labeled (a, b, c):

*   **(a) Name:** A single-line text field for the test name.
*   **(b) Location:** A single-line text field, followed by an information/help icon (question mark symbol).
*   **(c) Notes:** A multi-line text area (resizable) for detailed notes, followed by an information/help icon.

**Instructional Text:**
A light blue instruction box is located below the input fields, providing guidance:
"Specify a name for your USB Drive Test. You can optionally add details to the Location and Notes fields. After creating the test, you will see the additional steps that you will need to take before starting the test."

**Primary Action:**
*   **(d) Action Button:** A primary blue button labeled "Create USB Drive Test."
images.context: Click Create USB Drive Test once all details are entered.

images.alt:
This image displays a data grid used for testing file handling and security features.

**UI Elements and Structure:**
The interface consists of a sortable table with three primary columns:

1.  **Download Test File:** Lists the file name (hyperlinked in blue, suggesting download capability) and extension.
2.  **Opens:** A numerical field tracking the number of times the test file has been opened (currently populated with '0' for all entries).
3.  **Macro Enabled:** A status field indicating whether a macro associated with the file was enabled during opening.

**Content and Context:**
The table includes seven test files categorized by type and macro capability:

*   **Microsoft Office Documents (Standard, Macro-Free):** `Word.docx`, `Powerpoint.pptx`, `Excel.xlsx`. These entries show `N/A` in the "Macro Enabled" column.
*   **Microsoft Office Documents (Legacy/Macro-Enabled):** `Word With Macro.doc`, `Powerpoint With Macro.pps`, `Excel With Macro.xls`. These show `0` in the "Macro Enabled" column, suggesting the macro either did not execute or was not detected as enabled.
*   **PDF Document:** `PDF.pdf`. This shows `N/A` in the "Macro Enabled" column.

All column headers are equipped with sorting indicators (up/down arrows). Current data reflects initial conditions or zero execution counts across all metrics.
images.context: You can download and use multiple test files in a single USB drive test.

images.alt: A user interface element, specifically a rectangular push button with rounded corners, is displayed. The button has a solid blue background (color code approximating #3A8DD5). The button contains the text "Start Test" in white, sans-serif font, center-aligned. This UI component is intended to initiate a testing procedure or sequence.

images.alt:
The image displays a results page for an "Initial USB Test" activity within a web application, providing detailed metadata, file activity tracking, and status information.

**A. Test Identification and Metadata:**

1.  **Title:** The page is titled "Initial USB Test."
2.  **Navigation:** A link in the top right provides navigation back: "← Back to USB Drive Tests."
3.  **Test Parameters (Top Block):**
    *   Started on: 04/14/2023, 1:20 PM
    *   Location: Community kitchen, next to refrigerator
    *   Notes: This test is prior to training.
4.  **View Selection:** Two tabs are present: "Overview" (active) and "Details."

**B. Status Panel (Right Sidebar):**

1.  The panel is labeled "⚙ This Test" with an "Edit" link.
2.  **Status:** Started (in green text).
3.  **Started on:** 12/03/2021, 3:21 PM (Note: This start date conflicts with the metadata date listed above).
4.  **Completed on:** Incomplete (in a pale red/brown text).

**C. File Activity Data Table:**

1.  A table displays the downloadable test files and associated interaction metrics.
2.  **Columns (Sortable):** Download Test File, Opens, Macro Enabled.
3.  **Recorded Activity:** Seven files are listed, including various formats (.docx, .doc, .pptx, .pps, .xlsx, .xls, .pdf).
    *   The file "Excel With Macro.xls" shows successful interaction with counts of 1 for "Opens" and 1 for "Macro Enabled." All other files show "0" for Opens, or "N/A" for Macro Enabled status.

**D. Instructions and Controls:**

1.  **Instructional Block:** A light blue banner instructs the user to download the documents, rename them, place them on USB drives, and then "start the test to record the activity."
2.  **Action Button:** A dark blue button labeled "End Test" is present below the instructions.

**E. Geolocation Visualization:**

1.  **Title:** "Failures by IP Address Location," sub-captioned "In United States."
2.  **Visualization:** A map outlining the US states is displayed.
3.  **Data Point:** A single failure event is marked and labeled at "Ashburn, VA."
4.  **Legend:** A blue circle at the bottom indicates the symbol for "Failure."
5.  **UI Element:** Standard map zoom controls (+/-) are visible on the left edge of the map frame.

images.alt:
This image is a technical screenshot displaying the detailed results page for a specific "USB Test" in a web application interface.

**Header and Context:**
*   **Title:** "Initial USB Test" (H1 text, preceded by an icon of a list).
*   **Navigation:** A link in the top right corner reads "← Back to USB Drive Tests".
*   **Metadata:** Key test details are listed below the title:
    *   **Started on:** 04/14/2023, 1:20 PM
    *   **Location:** Community kitchen, next to refrigerator
    *   **Notes:** This test is prior to training.

**Tabbed Interface and Controls:**
*   A tabbed navigation system is present, with "Overview" (selected but inactive in this view) and "Details" (actively selected).
*   A functional link labeled "Download CSV Report" (with a green download icon) is located above the data table.
*   A search bar is positioned directly above the table for filtering data, labeled "Search" with a magnifying glass icon.

**Data Table (Details Tab):**
The primary content is a sortable data table detailing file access events. It displays one row of data:

| Column Header (Sortable) | Data Point |
| :--- | :--- |
| **File Type** | xlsm |
| **Opened at** | 12/03/2021, 3:22 PM |
| **Macro Enabled at** | 12/03/2021, 3:22 PM |
| **IP Address** | [Pii Masked] |
| **IP Location** | Ashburn, VA |
| **Username** | [Pii Masked] |
| **Display Name** | [Pii Masked] |
| **Computer Name** | BA-1479 |

**Footnote/Warning:**
A light blue banner is positioned below the table containing a critical informational note: "Username, Display Name, and Computer Name information are only available if the macro was enabled."
images.context: the table will also display the user's username, display name, and computer name.
